items.title: Together a Century, City and Oil Giant Hit a Rough Patch
items.abstract: Chevron has spent millions in recent years trying to shore up its relationship with Richmond, Calif., but many residents still oppose the company’s efforts to repair a refinery hit by a fire.

items.title: Hurricane Cost City at Least $154 Million in Overtime
items.abstract: Eighty-one percent of the total went to the Police and Sanitation Departments alone, according to a report released Friday by the Independent Budget Office.

items.title: City Names 17 Schools Slated to Close
items.abstract: New York City education officials released the first round of names of schools to be shut down, with more names coming on Tuesday.
keywords: High School of Graphic Communication Arts

items.title: Nashville’s Latest Big Hit Could Be the City Itself
items.abstract: The city, which sat on the sidelines while its Southern sisters boomed, has found itself in the national spotlight, with economic gains and a newly found popularity.

items.title: New York City to Restrict Prescription Painkillers in Public Hospitals’ Emergency Rooms
items.abstract: In an effort to crack down on drug abuse, most patients at the 11 hospitals will no longer be able to get more than three days’ worth of narcotic painkillers like Vicodin and Percocet.

items.title: De Blasio Names Herminia Palacio as Deputy Mayor for Health and Human Services
items.abstract: The appointment of Dr. Palacio, 54 and a native of the Bronx, fills a key role in the city’s efforts to confront a rise in homelessness.

items.title: Municipal Identification Card Program Offers Free Cultural Benefits
items.abstract: Enrollment in the program includes free annual memberships to 40 institutions. Here’s a borough-by-borough list of highlights.

items.title: Pritzker Prize for Architecture Is Awarded to Alejandro Aravena of Chile
items.abstract: Mr. Aravena, who has focused on low-cost social housing and reconstructing after natural disasters, received the honor as Chile emerges as a locus of noteworthy architecture.

items.title: Kansas City Chiefs at New England Patriots Preview
items.abstract: Kansas City, winner of 11 straight, looks to upset New England on Saturday.

items.title: Michigan’s Failure to Protect Flint
items.abstract: The state, which had played down findings of high levels of lead in the city’s water, must step in to find solutions.

items.title: As His Parting Gift, Urban Meyer Gives Ohio State a Rose Bowl Victory
items.abstract: The coach, who served a suspension earlier this season, had already announced his retirement, but he coached his team to a win over Washington in his final game.

items.title: The Army, in Need of Recruits, Turns Focus to Liberal-Leaning Cities
items.abstract: Too few recruits are signing up from cities like Chicago and Seattle, so the Army is trying to frame enlistment as a patriotic detour.
keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces

items.title: Some Workers Need Jobs as Much as Builders Need Workers. Cities Connect Them.
items.abstract: In tight labor markets, developers and local leaders are using major projects to provide residents with careers in construction.

items.title: N.Y. Today: When Schools Are Designed for Black Children
items.abstract: Afrocentric schools tend to have higher graduation rates and test scores. Also, what President Trump and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez have in common.

items.title: N.Y. Today: The Mayor’s Vision for the City
items.abstract: Mayor de Blasio has already announced major policies, so what’s the teleprompter for? Also, “Brooklyn Nine-Nine” returns.

items.title: Eric Adams Takes Office as New York City’s 110th Mayor at a Perilous Moment
items.abstract: Eric Adams, the city’s second Black mayor, faces difficult decisions over how to lead New York City through the next wave of the pandemic.

items.title: City Schools Are ‘Staying Open,’ Mayor Eric Adams Says
items.abstract: But the spike in Omicron cases has created trepidation for many parents.

items.title: City Ballet Pushes Back Start of Winter Season, Citing Omicron
items.abstract: The company will delay the start of its season by nine days, the latest performing arts group to cancel or postpone programming as the virus surges.

items.title: New York Plans to Install ‘Vending Machines’ With Anti-Overdose Drugs
items.abstract: In addition to naloxone, a medication used to reverse opioid overdoses, the machines will distribute free syringes, toiletries and safe-sex kits.

items.title: Broadway has been upended, but the Metropolitan Opera has yet to miss a performance.
items.abstract: The Omicron variant has toppled a slew of Broadway shows, disrupted dance productions, postponed festivals, forced the cancellation of dozens of concerts, and closed the mighty Vienna State Opera for almost a week. But it has yet to stymie the Metropolitan Opera, the largest American performing arts organization, which has not missed a performance this season.
